title: Is 'I knew little about that' and 'I little knew about that' both correct? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: They are both correct, but they both lean toward being an archaic useage. Using little as an adverb, to say “I little knew about that”, is the more archaic of the two, because it reflects a language seen pretty much only in far older literature, perhaps even poetic, older literature. I can’t give you a specific quote, but my mind’s ear hears “I little knew—-” as emoting Emily Dickinson. So far as ‘I knew little about that”, in today’s style we would be more likely to say “I knew a little about that”, or I knew just a little about that.” There is nothing necessarily wrong with archaic or outdated useage; it isn’t uncommon to use it for effect, for emphasis—-but it does sometimes strike the ear of the listener in an odd way.

They seem overly formal but yes they are both correct. They mean different things. ‘I knew little about that.’ =I did not know very much about something but I know about it. ‘I little knew about that.’ =I may only have heard about something in passing and did not really process that I know at all.
